content.question: The proposed rate-determining step for a reaction is <math alttext="2 N O 2 gas reacts to produce N O 3 gas plus N O gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext> </mtext><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>â†’</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>+</mo><mtext>NO</mtext><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. The graph above shows the distribution of energies for <math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules at two temperatures. Based on the graph, which of the following statements best explains why the rates of disappearance of <math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> are different at temperature 2 and temperature 1 ?

choices.label: <math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is consumed at a faster rate at temperature 2 because more molecules possess energies at or above the minimum energy required for a collision to lead to a reaction compared to temperature 1.

<math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is consumed at a faster rate at temperature 2 because the molecules have a wider range of energies allowing for a better orientation during a collision compared to temperature 1.

Fewer <math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules have a relatively high energy at temperature 1, which favors collisions between molecules rather than between the molecules and the container, leading to a faster rate of disappearance compared to temperature 2.

More <math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules have a relatively low energy at temperature 1, which increases the number of effective collisions taking place and the rate of disappearance compared to temperature 2.

content.answer: <math alttext="N O 2 gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is consumed at a faster rate at temperature 2 because more molecules possess energies at or above the minimum energy required for a collision to lead to a reaction compared to temperature 1.

skill.text: 6.E: Provide reasoning to justify a claim using connections between particulate and macroscopic scales or levels.
